We can find the area by counting the number of unit squares that the shape covers.

These rectangles do not have an area of $8$ square units.

hints.content:
Shapes can look different but still have the same area. 

Let’s find more shapes that can have an area of $6$ square units but have different side lengths than the rectangle above.

One way to make a rectangle with an area of $6$ square units is with $1$ row of $6$ square units anywhere on the graph.
